Award.AwardTitle: Beyond the Standard Model Searches using Mono-Boson Final States and the ATLAS Pixel Detector Upgrade
Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to search for physics that does not have an explanation in the Standard Model (SM), the theory that classifies all the known elementary particles. Using the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN (the particle European laboratory in Switzerland) this group of scientists will look for events in the ATLAS multi-particle detector where a Z or W Boson (identified by observing electrons or muons to which it decays) is observed moving away from the proton-proton interaction point in the LHC, accompanied by an object that leaves no visible tracks in the detector. This final state can probe many fundamental mysteries of the Universe, e.g. the nature of dark matter, the existence of extra dimensions, and the existence of an extended family of Higgs Bosons predicted by some theories beyond the SM. This group will also play a role in the planned upgrade of the ATLAS detector itself. They will work on the development and use of a device that uses silicon detectors to map out the paths of charged particles passing through. This award will support one PI, a postdoctoral fellow and a graduate student. The PI will continue as a mentor in the U. Washington QuarkNet program, and will also work with high school students from local Seattle High Schools in the MasterClass program. He will also continue to organize events that bring results from the LHC closer to the public.

The group will focus on W/Z + large EtransT events in which the particle recoiling against the Boson is invisible and has large, missing transverse energy. Such events would signal the existence of massive neutral particles that could have a number of origins in a variety of theories that lie beyond the SM. The group will also work on data acquisition for use with the ATLAS inner tracker.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Intellectual Merit of this proposal lies in the search for Beyond the Standard Model Physics at the LHC in an interesting channel with novel tools. Weakly interacting massive particles (WIMP) might be pair produced in association with a gauge boson which further decays hadronically. This can lead to a unique signature of large transverse missing energy and a hadronic boson moving with relativistically high transverse momentum. A new tool is developed to improve the identification of these highly boosted bosons and enhanced the discovery sensitivity by 30%. Even though there is no anomalous excess observed with 3.2fb-1 proton-proton collision data at a center-of-mass energy of 13TeV,  the results set the best constrain on several effective field theories and simplified models which contain WIMP candidates. They are also used to benchmark theory models which decay to di-boson final state and one of the boson decays hadronically while the other is a Z boson decaying to neutrino final states.

In terms of detector efforts, this project supports successful commissioning of the new layer of the ATLAS Pixel detector, named Insertable B-Layer. The efforts include data acquizition development and commissioning as well as the first software-based alignment of the new detector. These efforts are critical for reliable and robust data-taking quality and high precision measurement of the charged particle position.

The Broader Impact of this proposal is accomplished through three outreach activities organized by the PI and ran by the sponsored students during this funding period. These activities are highly integrated into the National QuarkNet program. They include Winter International  Masterclass, Spring LHC booth in the Paws-on-Science in the Pacific Science Center and Summer Cosmic Ray workshop. There are in total 6 high school teachers, 32 high school students, 7 volunteer undergraduate students and 3 graduate students involved. In particular, the LHC booth provides opportunities for UW students to interact with K-12 students by sharing their passion in science and frontier knowledge in particle physics.
